newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crudes quiet, levels steady to firmer.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crudes quiet, levels steady to firmer.

text.p: North Sea crude oil markets saw a quiet start to the week as traders awaited the remaining May loading programmes. Some saw continuing downward pressure on prompt cargoes but others felt current prices represented a good buying opportunity.
'It's time to stock up all the tanks if you haven't done it already,' one refiner said.
Differentials did seem to be improving even on grades such as Statfjord which, at the start of the day, had four unsold cargoes in the April 20-25 period.
An April 23-25 Statfjord was bought by a refiner on Monday at Dated Brent -3 cents, while over two million barrels of end month Forties changed hands at dated Brent +6 cents.
Sellers pointed out that 600Kb cargoes carried a premium as they gave buyers a freight advantage.
An April 23-25 minimum sized cargo of Brent crude oil was bought by a refiner at May Brent -55 cents.
An end month Troll was heard to have been sold but price details were not immediately available.
Intermonth Brent paper spreads held steady despite gains on outright levels following the NYMEX gasoline lead.
Brent May/June talked around -23/-21 cents after an early trade at -20 cents. June/July traded twice at -11 cents and July/Aug moved twice at -9 cents and once at -10 cents.
After loosing ground early on, CFD's held at lower levels in thin trade. This week (April 14-18) moved at June Brent -67 cents, while April 21-25 moved at June -58 cents.
The week 28-02 week sold at June -53 cents.
The May Brent programme was expected to be released early on Tuesday and volume was expected to be up on the month.
